Police is liar! The Hong Kong Police Force admitted a male officer had entered an antenatal ward, and was found to sneakily deleting a hashtag.
On Monday (7 October) night, police arrested a 19-year-old pregnant woman in street clothes at Siu Hong Stop, a light rail station. This sparked rumours online stating that a male police officer had entered the delivery room of the woman, which some believes to be an infringement of human rights. However, on 9 October around 6 p.m., the Hong Kong Police Force issued a statement on “Clarifying Rumours on Intrusion of Delivery Room for Guarding”, claiming that “At that time, the arrested person was located in the antenatal ward, which is a room that can accommodate 8 patients. The two police officers stayed outside the room for guarding, and did not enter the room.

Police is liar! The Hong Kong Police Force admitted a male officer had entered an antenatal ward, and was found to sneakily deleting a hashtag.
On Monday (7 October) night, police arrested a 19-year-old pregnant woman in street clothes at Siu Hong Stop, a light rail station. This sparked rumours online stating that a male police officer had entered the delivery room of the woman, which some believes to be an infringement of human rights. However, on 9 October around 6 p.m., the Hong Kong Police Force issued a statement on “Clarifying Rumours on Intrusion of Delivery Room for Guarding”, claiming that “At that time, the arrested person was located in the antenatal ward, which is a room that can accommodate 8 patients. The two police officers stayed outside the room for guarding, and did not enter the room.

replies.msg:
Part 2:
Yet, sources informed Apple Daily accusing that a male police officer had entered the ward, citing the reason as “statement taking”. The Police Force then posted a website of “Clarification of Tuen Mun Hospital on patient under custody” from the Health Authority, and pointed out that “the male police officer, accompanied by nurses and staff, had went inside an independent inspection room to verify information with the woman, and left the room immediately afterwards.” But the post was found to be sneakily edited. Originally, there was a hashtag “#Police officers had never gone inside the antenatal ward during the incident”, however, it as deleted after 40 minutes.
Sources also disclosed that the arrested pregnant woman was delivered to the hospital at around 11pm that night. The woman was suspected to have amniotic fluid leakage, and had to undergo checkups in the labour ward before entering the antenatal ward shown in online photos. The woman was escorted by two PSU officers, of which one male and one female. After the woman entered the labour ward, the male officer requested the ward supervisor to allow him to enter the ward, citing the reason “there is need to take a statement”. At some point, the officer was beside the woman while she was undergoing medical inspections. Sources also pointed out that there were other pregnant women awaiting delivery inside the ward at the same time.

Police is liar! The Hong Kong Police Force admitted a male officer had entered an antenatal ward, and was found to sneakily deleting a hashtag.
On Monday (7 October) night, police arrested a 19-year-old pregnant woman in street clothes at Siu Hong Stop, a light rail station. This sparked rumours online stating that a male police officer had entered the delivery room of the woman, which some believes to be an infringement of human rights. However, on 9 October around 6 p.m., the Hong Kong Police Force issued a statement on “Clarifying Rumours on Intrusion of Delivery Room for Guarding”, claiming that “At that time, the arrested person was located in the antenatal ward, which is a room that can accommodate 8 patients. The two police officers stayed outside the room for guarding, and did not enter the room.

replies.msg:
Part 3:
An insider questioned that the clarification statement from the Police Force avoided the incident that the male officer intentionally entered the ward, and even used a fabricated picture with the words “Male police officer entered the ward to guard?” to deliberately mislead the public. The insider also mentioned that it was already past midnight when the involved woman finished medical inspections and was delivered to the antenatal ward, which was not in the normal visiting hours. But police claimed that “there were other male relatives of patients present in areas outside the room”. Informed sources questioned that the story was made up. “Nobody would visit patients during that time period. How would there be other male passing by? It is not comparable to the situation under normal visiting hours.”
A spokesperson of Tuen Mun Hospital confirmed that the male police officer, accompanied by nurses and staff, had went inside an independent inspection room to verify information with the woman, but stressed that the officer had left the room immediately after finishing and waited at the family waiting area inside the ward. The spokesperson clarified that only medical staff was present when the pregnant woman was undergoing medical inspections inside the independent inspection room inside the ward.

replies.msg: Soon after the police denied that they have entered delivery room, a netizen, claimed to be a nurse in the hospital, said the male police officer has actually entered the delivery room. Public then felt shocked and doubted if the police told lies. One day later, the Police Force removed the statement and hospital side confirmed that male police officer has entered the delivery room to "verify personal information" with the pregnant woman.

No one would trust them again.
